_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Twin River Foods, Inc.

225 North Washington

Neosho, MO  64850





Twin River Foods chemical accident prevention and emergency response policies for ammonia refrigeration involve the development of this Risk Management Program and Plan (A?RMPA?) which has a primary objective of preventing an accidental  release of ammonia, and in the event there is one, minimize the consequences of a release.  



The stationary source subject to this RMP is Twin River FoodsA? poultry processing facility located in Neosho, MO.  The facility has one refrigeration system which contains anhydrous ammonia, a regulated substance under the RMP regulations.



The location has prepared a worst case release scenario, with distance to the toxic endpoint, using the ALOHA air dispersion modeling software. The alternate case release scenario, with distance to the toxic endpoint, was prepared using the RMPComp software. 



In accordance with RMP regulations, the general accidental release prevention program for this facilityA?s ammonia refrigeration system is comprised of the following components: process safety information, process hazard analysis, operating procedures, operator training, procedures for maintaining mechanical integrity, procedures for managing system changes, pre-start up safety review procedures, procedures for investigating release incidents, and hot work permit protocols.  This program was developed with the participation of the affected employees, and will be periodically audited for compliance required by the RMP regulations.  In addition, the facility has in place procedures for notifying contractors and their employees of the hazards of the system.  Chemical specific prevention steps are included within the program, including engineering and administration controls designed to prevent and minimize accidental releases.  



In the five years preceding the re-submittal of this RMP, this facility has had no accidentl releases. 



This facility has developed an Emergency

Action Plan which addresses accidental release of hazardous substances and has coordinated with the Newton County Local Emergency Planning Commission (A?LEPCA?).  The facility is included in the LEPCA?s community emergency response plan.
